details.title: Estimators for Reliability Measures in Geometric Distribution Model Using Dependent Masked System Life Test Data

p: Ammar M. Sarhan is a Professor of Statistics in the Department of Statistics and Operation Research, College of Science, King Saud University. He received his B.S. and M.S. in Mathematics from Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt in 1985 and 1989, respectively. He received his Ph.D. in Mathematical Statistics from Institute of Mathematics, Gdansk University, Poland in 1996. Originally, he works as an associated professor of Statistics in Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt. But now, he is working as a professor of Statistics under a contract with Department of Statistics and Operation Research, College of Science, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia. His research interests include Statistical Inferences, Reliability Analysis, Competing Risks Models, Statistical Computing, and Multivariate distributions.

Frank M. Guess is Full Professor of Statistics in the College of Business Administration at the University of Tennessee, where he served as the CBA Statistics Ph.D. Director from 1999 to 2004. He earned the Frank Wilcoxon's Best First Year Student in Applied Statistics Award in 1979 and the Ralph Bradley Ph.D. Student Award for outstanding achievement in 1984, both at Florida State University's Department of Statistics. Dr. Guess has had grants from IBM, Air Force Office of Scientific Research, and the Army Office of Research. He has been an Invited Program Committee Member at the Fourth International Reliability Research Conference held at the University of Missouri, Columbia, June, 1991 and also served as an invited Program Committee Member of the First International Research Conference on Lifetime Data Models held at Harvard University, co-sponsored by the Statistics Department at Harvard University, June, 1994. More recently, he served on the Program Committee for the International Workshop on Reliability and Its Applications in Seoul, Korea, December 2003, co-sponsored by the United States National Science Foundation and the Korean Reliability Society (KORAS) in cooperation with Rutgers University, USA and Hanyang University, Korea. Dr. Guess has spoken at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's (MIT) Sloan School of Management Information Quality Conference in 1999 and 2000, with his students presenting joint work in 2002 and 2003. He was on the Invited Program Committee in 2005 for the 10th Anniversary MIT's Information Quality Conference, plus also serves on the Program Committee for 2006 and 2007 MIT conference. He is on the Editorial Board of the International Journal of Reliability and Applications. He has written over 30 papers in reliability and statistics in Annals of Statistics, Journal of Statistical Planning & Inference, Quality and Reliability Engineering: International, IE News: Quality Control & Reliability Engineering, IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Biometrics, Biometrika. Reliability Review, Journal of Royal Statistical Society, etc.

John S. Usher Ph.D., P.E. is a Professor and Chairman of the Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of Louisville in Louisville, KY. He received his B.S. and M.Eng. degrees in Industrial Engineering from the University of Louisville in 1980 and 1981 respectively. He received his Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering from North Carolina State University in 1987. He has been actively involved in teaching, consulting, scholarly research, and service to the fields of quality control, reliability engineering, and facilities planning. Dr. Usher is a Fellow of the Institute of Industrial Engineers, and a Past President of the College Industry Council on Material Handling Education (CIC-MHE). He is a member of IIE, ASQC and IEEE, and is a Licensed Professional Engineer in the Commonwealth of Kentucky. In March of 2001, Dr. Usher was recognized by the University of Louisville for career teaching excellence and presented with the Distinguished Teaching Professor Award.

details.abstract: Masked system life test data arises when the exact component which causes the system failure is unknown. Instead, it is assumed that there are two observable quantities for each system on the life test. These quantities are the system life time, and the set of components that contains the component leading to the system failure. The component leading to the system failure may be either completely unknown (general masking), isolated to a subset of system components (partial masking), or exactly known (no masking). In the dependent masked system life test data, it is assumed that the probability of masking may depend on the true cause of system failure. Masking is usually due to limited resources for diagnosing the cause of system failures, as well as the modular nature of the system. In this paper, we present point, and interval maximum likelihood, and Bayes estimators for the reliability measures of the individual components in a multi-component system in the presence of dependent masked system life test data. The life time distributions of the system components are assumed to be geometric with different parameters. Simulation study will be given in order to 1) compare the two procedures used to derive the estimators for the reliability measures of system components, 2) study the influence of the masking level on the accuracy of the estimators obtained, and 3) study the influence of the masking probability ratio on the accuracy of the estimators obtained

links.abstract: This work estimates component reliability from masked series-system life data, viz, data where the exact component causing system failure might be unknown. The authors extend the results of Usher and Hodgson (1988) by deriving exact maximum likelihood estimators (MLE) for the general case of a series system of three exponential components with independent masking. Their previous work shows that closed-form MLE are intractable, and they propose an iterative method for the solution of a system of ...

references.text: D. K. Lin, J. S. Usher, F. M. Guess, "Exact maximum likelihood estimation using masked system data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-42, pp. 631-635, 1993.

references.title: Estimation of the geometric survival distribution

context.text: Lui [6] discussed both point, and interval estimation of the reliability function for the geometric distribution.

links.abstract: This paper discusses both point and interval estimation of the survivor function S/sub 0/=Pr{X/spl ges/x/sub 0/} for the geometric distribution. When the number of devices n/spl ges/50, the performance of the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) and uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimator (UMVUE) of S/sub 0/ are essentially equivalent with respect to the relative mean-square-error (RMSE) to S/sub 0/. However, when the failure probability per time unit p/spl ges/0.50, and n/spl les/30, the UM...

references.text: K. J. Lui, "Estimation of the geometric survival distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-46, pp. 134-144, 1997.

references.title:
Analysis of incomplete data in competing
risks model

context.text: Miyakawa [8] studied the problem of a 2-component series system when the system's components have constant failure rates.

links.abstract: Parametric and nonparametric estimation methods are proposed for reliability characteristics of one failure mode under competing risks with incomplete data; some of the failure times are observed without observing the cause of failure. The efficiencies of these methods are discussed.

references.text: M. Miyakawa, "Analysis of incomplete data in competing risks model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-33, pp. 293-296, 1984.

measures in the discrete case

references.title:
Testing equality of binomial parameters
based on inverse sampling

context.text: For example, consider switches or circuit-breakers, or those devices which operate in cycles or demands; for more details, we refer for example to Roy & Gupta [9], and Salvia [10].
Testing the equality of failure probability per time-unit among several comparison groups for the geometric distribution is considered by Salvia [10], and Vit [15].

links.abstract: Several dichotomous (pass/fail) populations are sampled until the first failure is observed in each population. A likelihood ratio test for the hypothesis of identical populations is presented. Results also apply to repeated sampling from a single population.

references.text: A. A. Salvia, "Testing equality of binomial parameters based on inverse sampling", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-33, pp. 377-378, 1984.

references.title:
Parameter estimations in linear failure
rate model using masked data

context.text: Sarhan [11] derived Bayes, and maximum likelihood estimators of the unknown parameters in the case of a series system when the lifetime of each component follows a distribution with a linear failure rate.

references.text: A. M. Sarhan, "Parameter estimations in linear failure rate model using masked data", Applied Mathematics and Computation, vol. 151, pp. 233-249, 2004.

references.title:
Estimation of system components
reliabilities using masked data

context.text: The maximum likelihood estimators for the parameters included in the cases of 2-component, and 3-component series systems are derived under the assumption that the lifetime distributions of the components are Weibull; see Sarhan [12].

references.text: A. M. Sarhan, "Estimation of system components reliabilities using masked data", Applied Mathematics and Computation, vol. 136/1, pp. 79-92, 2003.

references.text: A. M. Sarhan, "Reliability estimation of components from masked system life data", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 74/1, pp. 107-113, 2001.

context.text: Therefore, these estimates can be used, under some certain conditions, to predict the reliability of a new configuration of components in a new system; see Usher [17].
An iterative maximum likelihood procedure is used by Usher [17] in the case of a 2-component series system when the system's component life times are Weibull distributed.

links.abstract: Analysts are often interested in obtaining component reliabilities by analyzing system-life data. This is generally done by making a series-system assumption and applying a competing-risks model. These estimates are useful because they reflect component reliabilities after assembly into an operational system under true operating conditions. The fact that most new systems under development contain a large proportion of old technology also supports the approach. In practice, however, this type of ...

references.text: J.S. Usher, "Weibull component reliability—Prediction in the presence of masked data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-45, pp. 229-232, 1996.

references.title:
Maximum likelihood analysis of component
reliability using masked system life-test data

context.text: Usher & Hodgson [18] extended Miyakawa's results to a three-component series system using the same assumption that the failure rates of the components are constant.
He derived closed-form expressions for maximum likelihood estimates in some particular cases, which generalize the results obtained by Usher & Hodgson [18].

links.abstract: Life data from multicomponent systems are often analyzed to estimate the reliability of each system component. Due to the cost and diagnostic constraints, however, the exact cause of system failure might be unknown. Referring to such situations as being masked, the authors use a likelihood approach to exploit all the available information. They focus on a series system of three components, each with a constant failure rate, and propose a single numerical procedure for obtaining maximum-likelihoo...

references.text: J. S. Usher, T. J. Hodgson, "Maximum likelihood analysis of component reliability using masked system life-test data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-37, pp. 550-555, 1988.
